results.title: Proud 2 Be Me!
results.creator_credit: Amy Rowe, Charlotte Kinsella, Chloe McKenna, Hannah Petrowski, Isabelle Tonna, Jessica Smith and Leah Felsbourg
results.brief_description:
A story of a little, white monster who feels like he doesn’t belong. He tries to make himself fit in, which doesn’t quite work out. The other little monsters finally decide that they like the little white monster just the way he is.

Under the category ‘Bullying. No Way! - Primary’, Years 5 and 6, St Luke’s Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Cubbies
results.creator_credit: Darcy Drake, Kane Jutson, Max Duke and Ryan Dunt
results.brief_description:
Trust, creativity, friendship and belonging are the focus of the ‘Cubbies’ story. A group of friends use cooperation, creativity and sheer ingenuity to build 29 different ‘cubbies’. The trust given by the staff and wider school community is central.

Under the categories ‘Primary Live Action’ and ‘Best Overall Primary’, Years 5 and 6 from Doreen Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Unshaded
results.brief_description:
‘Unshaded’ is a stop-motion animation made from plasticine. It explores the notion that no matter who you are, there is always a place of belonging for you. The animation is initially shot in a black and white world, reflecting the character’s thoughts of loneliness and insecurity. The character is confronted by unfamiliar creatures who seek to gain their colour back by signalling to him to tap them on the head. He does this and in return his world is restored to colour. The character realises that together they can bring happiness to each other and ultimately belong even though they may have evident differences.

Under the category ‘Secondary Animation’, Hayley Warnock, Benalla, Victoria, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

results.title: You don't belong here [game trailer]
results.brief_description:
By staying true to your own ideals you will find a group of unique individuals where everyone belongs. A man is shipwrecked on a distant island. He must search the island for a tribe to live in by avoiding obstacles and collecting gems along the way. These tribes will take you in but on the condition you behave like them. You decline their offer saying you have a right to be yourself. You are then banished and must avoid members of these tribes as you continue your search. They attempt to catch you as you dont belong. Finally you come across a tribe that accepts you for who you are. They are all individuals and make you feel like you belong.

Under the category ‘Primary Videogames’, Liam Blake, Hope Valley, SA, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: Aden Porter, Joshua Ash-Miller, Laurence Gunther and Schonn-Pierre Hirst
results.brief_description:
The theme of belonging is explored by looking at rejection based on stereotypes in the schoolyard, and the effect that had on the victim. Also shown in this animated short is the impact an accepting group has on that person.

Under the category ‘Bullying. No Way! - Secondary”, Year 10, St John’s Grammar School, South Australia, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Wish
results.creator_credit: Araine Moir, Elizabeth Kuiper and Emily Abernethy
results.brief_description:
A young girl is transported into a fantasy world where her birthday wishes manifest into something beyond her control. This film questions the importance we place on superficial and materialistic desires.

Under the category ‘Best Overall Secondary School Entry’, Year 12, Presbyterian Ladies’ College, Peppermint Grove, WA, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: The Respect Quest [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Christopher Halse, Liam Blake and Tea Tree Gully Primary School
results.brief_description:
Time Monsters are spreading disrespect in the community and causing havoc. Help local villagers and elders restore respect by defeating the Time Monsters with a magic boomerang. Jump on platforms, collect coins and explore through the mountains of time. Money gained on the quest will help rebuild the villages after respect is restored.

This trailer illustrates how the game is played.
Under the category ‘Primary Games’, Tea Tree Gully Primary School’s Liam Blake and Christopher Halse, Grade 5, were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: Twin [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: James Ruse Agricultural High and Nicholas Lee
results.brief_description:
‘Twin’ is a videogame that highlights the importance of self-respect. It is based upon the Hero’s search for those who took away his ‘colour’. As his colour has been taken away, he has been reduced to his black and white form; his own being is split into two. The Hero realises his colour was in fact not stolen and by being able to overcome the puzzles and challenges brought by each level, the Hero begins to respect himself and is ultimately able to retrieve his ‘colours.’

A 2D problem solving/puzzle showing respect starts with self. This trailer illustrates how the game is played.
Under the category ‘Secondary Games’, James Ruse Agricultural High School’s Nicholas Lee, Year 12, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: The World As We Know It
results.creator_credit: Shannon Castle and Sunbury Downs College
results.brief_description:
A figure, shown by stop-motion animation, much like a zombie, walks through a world in pain. The Earth and people on it are being treated unfairly. Only if the figure wakes up to the fact that we need to respect the world and its inhabitants will the world become a better place.
Under the category ‘Secondary Animation’, Sunbury Downs College’s Shannon Castle, Year 9, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: Buzz Off
results.brief_description:
This clay-animated story is about respect for others who are different or have different cultures. Overcome by Bees, The Jewel Beetles must flee their home to find a safe place to live. Forced to brave a treacherous river and evade hungry predators, the Jewel Beetles reach the safety of Grasshopper Land. They overhear a debate between two grasshoppers. One grasshopper believes that beetles would bring new perspectives and cultures to Grasshopper Land, while the other grasshopper, fearing change, thinks the beetles don’t belong. Intolerance or acceptance will determine the Jewel Beetles’ fate.
Under the category ‘Primary Animation’, Yarraville West Primary School’s 5/6 Film Team were the Screen It 2011 winners.
